case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 16, 1954 of Hyderabad High Court in Reference No. 347/B-5/2 of 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 16, 1954, of the former Hyderabad High Court in Reference No. 347/B- 5/2 of 1953-54.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, is the appellant before us.

facts.text: Respondent is Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd., a public limited company incorporated in erstwhile State of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd., a public limited companypany incorporated in the erstwhile State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: Respondent assessed under Hyderabad Income-tax Act for assessment years 1357-F, 1358-F and 1359-F.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany was assessed under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act in respect of the assessment years 1357-F, 1358-F and 1359-F.

facts.text: Depreciation allowance given on written down value of assets under cl. c of s. 125 of Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment for those years depreciation allowance was given to it on the basis of the written down value of its assets, such as buildings, machinery, plant, etc., in accordance with the provisions of cl.  c  of s. 12 5  of the Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Erstwhile State of Hyderabad merged in Union of India on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The erstwhile State of Hyderabad merged in the Union of India on January 26, 1950, and became a Part B State.

facts.text: Finance Act, 1950 by s.13 repealed taxation laws in Part B States and by s.3 extended Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 to whole of India except Jammu and Kashmir.

anchor.surface_text: The Finance Act, 1950, by s. 13 thereof repealed the taxation laws in force in Part B States except for certain purposes number relevant to this case, and by s. 3 extended the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, to the whole of India except the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

facts.text: Central Government made Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 by notification dated December 2, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, the Central Government was pleased to make the Taxation Laws  Part B States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1950  hereinafter referred to as the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 , by a numberification dated December 2, 1950.

facts.text: Paragraph 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 provides for computation of aggregate depreciation allowance and written down value taking into account depreciation actually allowed under Part B State laws.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 2 of the said Order, in so far as it is relevant to this case, was in these terms Computation of aggregate depreciation allowance and written down value In making any assessment under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules of a Part B State, relating to Income-tax and Super- tax, or any law relating to tax on profits of business, shall be taken into account in companyputing the aggregate depreciation allowance referred to in sub-clause  c  of the proviso to clause  vi  of sub-section  2  and the written down value under clause  b  of sub-section  5  of sec. 10 of the said Act.

facts.text: Respondent assessed for first time under Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 for assessment year 1951-52 (account year ending June 30, 1950) read with paragraph 5 of Part B States Taxation Concessions Order, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52 which was in respect of the account year ending June 30, 1950, the respondent was assessed for the first time under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, read with paragraph 5 of the Part B States  Taxation Concessions  Order, 1950.

facts.text: Respondent claimed depreciation allowance of Rs.8,12,244 based on paragraph 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, computing written down value as actual cost minus depreciation allowed under Hyderabad Act.

anchor.surface_text: Basing its claim on paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, the respondent asked for depreciation allowance in respect of its assets such as buildings, machinery, plant, etc., to the tune of Rs.8,12,244. It worked out the value of the assets at their inception and deducted therefrom such depreciation as was allowed for the three assessment years in which the respondent was assessed under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act and calculating the written down value in that manner, it claimed depreciation according to the prescribed rates.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed respondent's claim by order dated November 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated November 30, 1951, the Income-tax Officer disallowed this claim.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO's order by order dated May 23, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: That Officer by an order dated May 23, 1952, upheld the view of the Income-tax Officer and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal allowed respondent's appeal by order dated December 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated December 12, 1952, the Appellate Tribunal held that in view of the pro- visions in paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, the companytention of the respondent must prevail

facts.text: Central Government added Explanation to paragraph 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 on March 9, 1953 under s.60A of Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, that is, on March 9, 1953, the Central Government purporting to exercise its powers companyferred by s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, added an Explanation to paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950.

facts.text: Tribunal stated case to High Court on question of law regarding computation of written down value for 1951-52 assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It said finally that the following question of law did arise out of its order and accordingly stated a case thereon Whether in making the assessment for the year 1951-52 under the Indian Income-tax Act is the assessee companypany entitled to claim depreciation allowance on the basis of the written down value companyputed at the time of the assessment for the year 1359-F, or is to be companyputed on the basis of the actual companyt minus the depreciation allowances granted under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Hyderabad High Court held Explanation of March 9, 1953 void and answered question in favour of respondent by order dated February 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was then heard by the High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad which by its order dated February 16, 1954, held that the Explanation added to paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, by the numberification dated March 9, 1953, was void on certain grounds one of which was that the Explanation was ultra vires the powers of the Central Government under s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate of fitness from High Court and preferred appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then obtained the necessary certificate of fitness and preferred the present appeal.

facts.text: Central Government issued notification No. S.O. 1139 dated May 8, 1956 adding identical Explanation to paragraph 2 under s.12 of Finance Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, there was a further change of law. On May 8, 1956, the Central Government made a numberification  No. S. O. 1139  in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, whereby an Explanation in identical terms as the earlier Explanation made under s. 60- A of the Indian Income-tax Act, was added to paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950.

facts.text: Supreme Court held 1956 notification valid and applicable, allowed appeal and answered question in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated February 16, 1954. The question referred to the High Court is answered in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: ITO took written down value from 1359-F proceedings and allowed depreciation on those figures.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, he took the figures of the written down value from the income-tax proceedings of 1359-F and allowed depreciation at the prescribed rate on those figures.

facts.text: Tribunal directed ITO to compute written down value as actual cost minus depreciation actually allowed under Hyderabad Act.

anchor.surface_text: It directed the Income-tax Officer to companypute the written down value on the basis of the actual companyt to the assessee of the assets in question minus the depreciation allowance actually allowed to the assessee under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

under s.66-A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, is the appellant before us. The respondent is Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd., a public limited companypany incorporated in the erstwhile State of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, that is, on March 9, 1953, the Central Government purporting to exercise its powers companyferred by s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, added an Explanation to paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950.

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to make orders for removal of difficulties

anchor.surface_text: We may first read s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, under which numberification No. S. R. O. 1139 dated May 8, 1956, was made. Section 12 reads If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of any of the Acts, rules or orders extended by section 3 or section 11 to any State or merged territory, the Central Government may by order, make such provision, or give such direction, as appears to it to be necessary for removing the difficulty .

concepts.interpretation: Confers power on Central Govt to remove difficulties retrospectively; notification valid under it

concepts.interpretation: No violation as assessees in different Part B State areas not similarly situated due to varying prior laws

anchor.surface_text: It was therefore necessary to explain paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, to assimilate or harmonise the position regarding depreciation allowance, and the Explanation added in 1953 or 1956 was obviously intended to remove the difficulty arising out of that disparity or disharmony.

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation, though added in 1956, explains the meaning of paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 and says in express terms that the paragraph shall be deemed always to have had that meaning.

concepts.interpretation: Valid retrospective effect as power under s.12 includes removing difficulty from when it arose; applies to 1951-52 assessment

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, the true scope and effect of s. 12 seems to be that it is for the Central Government to determine if any difficulty of the nature indicated in the section has arisen and then to make such order, or give such direction, as appears to it to be necessary to remove the difficulty. Parliament has left the matter to the executive but that does number make the numberification of 1956 bad. In Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. The State of Madhya Pradesh Ors.  1  we said at page 435 Now, the authorities are clear that it is number unconstitutional for the legislature to leave it to the executive to determine details relating to the working of taxation laws, such as the selection of persons on whom the tax is to be laid, the rates at which it is to be charged in respect of different classes of goods and the like .

concepts.interpretation: Valid delegation to executive for details in taxation laws

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ent case, which is an assessment for the year 1951-52 ? The numberification was made in 1956 and it added an Explanation to paragraph 2 of the Removal

concepts.unlisted_description: Legislature may delegate details of taxation to executive

It is companytended that this resultant discrimination is arbitrary and without any rational justification,

issues.text: Whether in making the assessment for the year 1951-52 under the Indian Income-tax Act is the assessee company entitled to claim depreciation allowance on the basis of the written down value computed at the time of the assessment for the year 1359-F, or is to be computed on the basis of the actual cost minus the depreciation allowances granted under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in making the assessment for the year 1951-52 under the Indian Income-tax Act is the assessee companypany entitled to claim depreciation allowance on the basis of the written down value companyputed at the time of the assessment for the year 1359-F, or is to be companyputed on the basis of the actual companyt minus the depreciation allowances granted under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

issues.text: whether the notification is validly made under s. 12 or is it ultra vires the powers conferred on the Central Government by that section

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the numberification is validly made under s. 12 or is it ultra vires the powers companyferred on the Central Government by that section ? On behalf of the respondent it is urged that a companydition for the exercise of the power under s. 12 is companytained in the opening clause, which says If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of any of the Acts, rules or orders extended by section 3 or section II to any State etc.

issues.text: does the notification apply to the assessment in the present case, which is an assessment for the year 1951-52

anchor.surface_text: The second question is-does the numberification apply  1  1959 S.C.R. 427. to the assessment in the present case, which is an assessment for the year 1951-52 ? The numberification was made in 1956 and it added an Explanation to paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950. It says that a particular expression occurring in that paragraph means and shall be deemed always to have meant the aggregate allowance for depreciation taken into account in companyputing the written down value etc., under any law of a Part B State.

issues.text: whether the notification of 1956 contravenes Art. 14 of the Constitution, because it discriminates between different classes of tax payers

anchor.surface_text: The last challenge to the validity of the numberification of 1956 is that it companytravenes Art. 14 of the Constitution, because it discriminates between different classes of tax payers. Learned Counsel for the respondent has asked us to companysider the cases of assessees in three different areas which subsequently companye in a Part B State in one area there was numberlaw relating to income-tax in, the second there was a law relating to income-tax under which written down value was companyputed on the basis of depreciation actually allowed year after year, while in the third the written down value was companyputed in the manner provided under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act it is pointed out that on the extension of the Indian Income- tax Act  read with paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 and the Explanation  to those areas, the assessee in the first area will get depreciation allowance on the actual companyt in the second area he will get such allowance on the basis of actual companyt less depreciation actually allowed and in the third area he will get such allowance on the actual companyt less depreciation taken into account. It is companytended that this resultant discrimination is arbitrary and without any rational justification,

It worked out the value of the assets at their inception and deducted therefrom such depreciation as was allowed for the three assessment years

arguments.court_reasoning: Explanation to para 2 deems 'actually allowed' to mean aggregate depreciation taken into account in computing WDV under Part B State laws; valid and retrospective

arguments.claim: Claim for depreciation is against the principle of decreasing depreciation allowance year to year; 'allowed' in para 2 means 'considered' i.e. aggregate in WDV computation under Hyderabad Act

anchor.surface_text: He held that the claim of the respondent was against the principle inherent in granting depreciation allowance which must decrease from year to year, and further held that the word allowed in paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, should be construed as meaning considered only.

arguments.claim: In view of para 2, assessee entitled to depreciation on actual cost minus depreciation actually allowed under Hyderabad Act; words mean actually allowed, not aggregate taken into account

anchor.surface_text: The reference was then heard by the High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad which by its order dated February 16, 1954, held that the Explanation added to paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, by the notification dated March 9, 1953, was void on certain grounds one of which was that the Explanation was ultra vires the powers of the Central Government under s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to examine 1953 as 1956 identical and valid

arguments.claim: 1956 notification valid under s.12 Finance Act, does not suffer defects of 1953, court must give effect to it as change in law for pending appeal

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it has been argued that the notification was validly made in exercise of the powers conferred on the Central Government under s. 12 aforesaid that it does not suffer from any of the defects pointed out by the High Court in regard to the earlier notification of 1953 made under s. 60-A of the Income-tax Act and that it adds an Explanation which in terms gives effect to the contention of the appellant and this Court must consider the change in law made thereby and give effect to it in answering the question of law arising out of the Tribunals order.

arguments.claim: 1956 notification contravenes Art.14 by discriminating between assessees in different Part B State areas with varying prior depreciation laws

anchor.surface_text: The last challenge to the validity of the notification of 1956 is that it contravenes Art. 14 of the Constitution, because it discriminates between different classes of tax payers. Learned Counsel for the respondent has asked us to consider the cases of assessees in three different areas which subsequently came in a Part B State in one area there was no law relating to income-tax in, the second there was a law relating to income-tax under which written down value was computed on the basis of depreciation actually allowed year after year, while in the third the written down value was computed in the manner provided under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ided under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act it is pointed out that on the extension of the Indian Income- tax Act  read with paragraph 2 of the Removal of

arguments.court_reasoning: Assessees not similarly situated due to different prior laws; treating differently not discriminatory

arguments.claim: Difficulty arose with para 2 as applied to Hyderabad Act leading to higher depreciation in first Indian Act year than prior, against scheme; Explanation harmonises depreciation treatment

anchor.surface_text: If, however, depreciation actually allowed under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act was taken into account in computing the aggregate depreciation allowance and the written down value, an anomalous result would follow as in the present case, namely, depreciation allowance to be allowed to the assessee in the accounting year under the Indian Income-tax Act would be more than what was allowed in previous years under the Hyderabad Income-tax Act. This would create a disparity and be against the scheme of the Indian Income-tax Act. It was therefore necessary to explain paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, to assimilate or harmonise the position regarding depreciation allowance,

arguments.claim: s.12 empowers Central Govt to determine if difficulty exists and remove it; valid delegation of legislative power for taxation details

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, the true scope and effect of s. 12 seems to be that it is for the Central Government to determine if any difficulty of the nature indicated in the section has arisen and then to make such order, or give such direction, as appears to it to be necessary to remove the difficulty. Parliament has left the matter to the executive but that does not make the notification of 1956 bad. In Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. The State of Madhya Pradesh Ors.  1  we said at page 435 Now, the authorities are clear that it is not unconstitutional for the legislature to leave it to the executive to determine details relating to the working of taxation laws,

arguments.claim: Assessees in different Part B areas with no prior IT law, actual dep law, or Hyderabad method not similarly situated for equal treatment under Explanation

anchor.surface_text: We think that learned Counsel for the respondent has ignored one essential consideration which clearly vitiates his argument. In the matter of depreciation allowance, the assessee in the three areas in the example given by him do not stand on the same footing they are not situated alike so as to be entitled to be treated alike.

arguments.claim: Valid change in law by 1956 notification applies to pending appeal before Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: It has not been disputed before us that a change in law validly made and applicable to a case pending in appeal must be considered and given effect to by the Appellate Court.

holdings.text: The notification of 1956 was validly made under s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950 and is not ultra vires the powers conferred on the Central Government by that section.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that the notification of 1956, was validly made under s. 12 and is not ultra vires the powers conferred on the Central Government by that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: A difficulty arose in applying para 2 leading to anomalous higher depreciation under Indian IT Act than prior Hyderabad Act; s.12 allows Central Govt to determine existence of difficulty and remove it via explanatory order; valid legislative delegation for taxation details per precedent in Pandit Banarsi Das.

holdings.text: The notification of 1956 applies to the assessment for 1951-52 as the Explanation deems para 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order always to have meant aggregate depreciation taken into account in computing written down value under Part B State laws.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government has, therefore, the power to make an order or give a direction so as to remove the difficulty from the very beginning, and that is what the notification of 1956 does. It applies to the assessment of 1951-52 indeed it applies to all assessments made under the Indian Income-tax Act in which paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, operates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation clarifies meaning of para 2 retrospectively; s.12 power to remove difficulty includes effect from when difficulty arose; applies to pending assessments including 1951-52.

holdings.text: The notification of 1956 does not contravene Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the challenge to the notification based on Art. 14 is wholly unsubstantial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessees in different Part B State areas with varying prior income-tax regimes (no law, actual allowed dep, or Hyderabad method) not similarly situated; differential treatment rational and not arbitrary.

holdings.text: In making the assessment for 1951-52, the assessee is entitled to depreciation allowance on the basis of written down value computed at the time of assessment for 1359-F under Hyderabad Act (aggregate depreciation taken into account), not actual cost minus depreciation actually allowed thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we allow this appeal and set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated February 16, 1954. The question referred to the High Court is answered in favour of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1956 notification validly interprets 'depreciation actually allowed' in para 2 as aggregate taken into account for WDV under Part B laws; applies retrospectively to 1951-52; appeal allowed.

holdings.text: A change in law validly made and applicable to a case pending in appeal must be considered and given effect to by the Appellate Court.

anchor.surface_text: It has not been disputed before us that a change in law validly made and applicable to a case pending in appeal must be considered and given effect to by the Appellate Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed principle applied to give effect to valid 1956 notification in pending Supreme Court appeal.
